text: This isn't emacs specific, but you can use the Python debugger by adding the following to a Django view function:
import pdb; pdb.set_trace()
Now when you run the development server and view the page, your browser will appear to hang or load very slowly - switch over to your console, and you have access to the full debugger.
You can inspect AND modify state of your application via an interactive shell - check out the Python documentation for the debugger, or this link for some Python debugging examples
If all you need is logging, add the following to your settings.py:

code:
logging.basicConfig(
    level = logging.DEBUG,
    format = '%(asctime)s %(levelname)s %(message)s',
    filename = '/tmp/mylog.log',
    filemode = 'w'
)

Because recent versions of Emacs python mode do support 'pdbtrack' functionality by default, all you need is just set up breakpoint in your code this way:
import pdb; pdb.set_trace()
Also, you  have to start your Django application devserver from within Emacs shell:
C-x shell
And so type there:
./manage.py runserver
P.S.
No need for specific pdb sessions or --noreload flag.
Noreload would require you to manually restart your applications and so I do not find this useful for Emacs.
